Yeh I think if I use the player comparison table format used in their 
paper that should be a good basis for comparison.

>> <>3)OCR - Optical Character Recognition. The plan is to expose a set 
>> of 2D <>bitmaps, in turn, to the inputs of an NN. The number of 
>> outputs will
>>
>>reflect the number of 2D maps in the current set, 
>>
>It might be easier to evolve a single classifier net for each 
>character, i.e. "is it or isn't it an 'a'?"  That obviously reduces 
>the output space a lot.  Then you could combine all these separate 
>networks into a single network and let NEAT evolve interconnections 
>to improve how they interact with each other...just an idea!
>  
>
Well this got me thinking. This comes under the heading of task 
decomposition [again], breaking down the one all-purpose network into 
multiple single-purpose networks. If I was looking for the best OCR 
network then I think this is a better approach and far more likely to 
give good results, especially as the number of characters increase. What 
I'm trying to do though is present a problem to NEAT that we know it 
will find difficult, so that we can measure any improvement. As a 
compromise between the two techniques I can vary the number of 
characters that I am trying to recognise, perhaps starting with just 3 or 4.

I think this makes sense, I am thinking that the phased-search approach 
is a way to improve the search through the topology space (because we 
trim away and build back up), but not the connection weights. The 
decomposed OCR technique you propose is largely a problem of searching 
through connection weights (I think) since I don't think it requires any 
hidden nodes to be solved. OK you still need to evolve the connections 
to start with, but the point is that the networks evolved will probably 
just connect each input directly to the output with no hidden nodes, and 
therefore the scope for improving the search as a whole by improving the 
topology searching is [very] limited.

Actually my approach doesn't /need/ hidden nodes either but it does have 
a larger input/output space to search, and also has [more] scope for 
using hidden nodes as the basis for representing character recognition 
strutures that can be reused for more than one character. e.g. where 
characters are very similar (c/e/o/q  or P/R/K) a hidden node might 
prepresent the detection of the common parts and then aditional 
structures detect only the differences.  This potentially makes for 
leaner, more efficient networks, though as you suggest, if we evolve 
individual networks we can combine them and perorm some more searching 
to make the combined netork more efficient - although I think deletion 
mutations would improve such an 'amalgamation' of sub-networks.

Colin
